entry.title: Almirante Barroso (Wikipedia — did you know?)
entry.content: ... that the Brazilian cruiser Almirante Barroso (pictured) was on a voyage to circumnavigate Earth with Prince August Leopold on board when the republic was proclaimed in Brazil?

entry.title: Updown Girl (Wikipedia — did you know?)
entry.content: ... that archaeologists found that Updown Girl, who was buried in England in the 7th century, had a mixture of West African and European DNA?

entry.title: Triassosculda (Wikipedia — did you know?)
entry.content: ... that until April 2023, when the genus Triassosculda was discovered, the mantis shrimp fossil record contained a gap of more than a hundred million years?

entry.title: Stephanie of Courtenay (Wikipedia — did you know?)
entry.content: ... that when Abbess Stephanie of Courtenay's niece's marriage to the king of Jerusalem was annulled, the court's reasoning was so flimsy that a noted jurist had to ask Stephanie to explain it to him?

entry.title: wood-pasture hypothesis (Wikipedia — did you know?)
entry.content: ... that the wood-pasture hypothesis posits that semi-open wood pastures and not primeval forests are the natural vegetation of temperate Europe?

entry.title: Julia Figueredo (Wikipedia — did you know?)
entry.content: ... that Julia Figueredo was the first indigenous woman to be elected president of La Paz's parliamentary delegation?

entry.title: the seventy cues (Wikipedia — did you know?)
entry.content: ... that fewer than half of the seventy cues composed by Dmitri Shostakovich for the 1971 film King Lear made it into the final cut?

entry.title: Poison (Wikipedia — did you know?)
entry.content: ... that the song "Poison" can soothe babies?
